fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Every kernel pair has a coequalizer

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In a regular category, every kernel pair has a coequalizer. Moreover, the given kernel pair is also a kernel pair of the coequalizer.

Let a , b \colon R \rightrightarrows A be the kernel pair of a morphism f \colon A \to B. Consider the cover-mono factorization of f: f = f_{m}f_{c}. By , it suffices to show that (a,b) is a kernel pair of f_{c}, i.e., the following diagram is a pullback.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = R, ne = A, sw = A, se = { \mathsf { Img } (f)}, north = b, west = a, south = {f_{c}}, south/style = {cover}, east = {f_{c}}, east/style = {cover}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: First, the diagram commutes since fa = f_{m}f_{c}a = f_{m}f_{c}b = fb by definition, and f_{m} is monic. Let h , k \colon C \rightrightarrows A be a pair of morphisms such that f_{c}h = f_{c}k. Then f_{m}f_{c}h = fh = fk = f_{m}f_{c}k. Thus, the unique factor is given by the following pullback.
In a regular category, every cover is a coequalizer of the kernel pair of itself.

Let p , q \colon C \rightrightarrows A be the kernel pair of a cover f \colon A \twoheadrightarrow B and g \colon A \to D be a morphism such that gp = gq. Consider the joint cover-mono factorization of f and g, i.e., the cover-mono factorization of the morphism (f,g) \colon A \to B \times D.

We show that f' and h form a cover-mono factorization of the cover f, so f' is an isomorphism. Suppose that f'a = f'b. We need to show that a = b. To this end, it suffices to show that g'a = g'b since f' and g' are jointly monic. Consider the joint pullback of a and b along h.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = \AA , nw/style = {pullback}, ne = A \times A, sw = E, se = \underline {A} \times \underline {A}, north = {(m,n)}, west = r, west/style = {cover}, south = {(a,b)}, east = h \times h, east/style = {cover}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Note that h \times h is a cover by , and since covers are stable under pullback in a regular category, r is also a cover. Now we have that
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} fm &= f'hm \\ &= f'ar && \text {by hypothesis $f'a = f'b$} \\ &= f'br \\ &= f'hn \\ &= fn \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Thus, m and n may be expressed in terms of the kernel pair of f.
To show g'a = g'b, it suffices to show g'ar = g'br since r is epic.
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} g'ar &= g'hm \\ &= gm \\ &= gps && \text {by hypothesis $gp = gq$} \\ &= gqs \\ &= gn \\ &= g'hn \\ &= g'br \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Finally, g can be factored as follows:
Uniqueness then follows from the fact that f is epic.

A category \mathcal { C } is said to be regular if it is cartesian, has images, and covers are stable under pullback. A functor F \colon \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { D } between regular categories is said to be regular if it is cartesian and preserves covers. Note that since cartesian functors preserve monomorphisms, every regular functor automatically preserves images.

Let F \colon \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { D } be a regular functor and f \colon A \to B be a morphism in \mathcal { C }. By , f admits a cover-mono factorization f = \mathsf { Img } (f) \vartheta _{f}. Then since F preserves monomorphisms and covers, F( \mathsf { Img } (f))F( \vartheta _{f}) forms a cover-mono factorization of F(f). Then by uniqueness, \mathsf { Img } (Ff) \cong F( \mathsf { Img } (f)).

Let (a,b) \colon R \rightarrowtail A \times A be an effective equivalence relation in a regular category. Then a , b \colon R \rightrightarrows A admit a coequalizer d. Moreover, (a,b) is a kernel pair of d.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By definition, (a,b) is a kernel pair of some morphism. Then the result follows immediately from .
